titleStmt.title: Suboptimal investment behavior and welfare costs: A simulation based approach

funder.orgName: Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo CientÈ¡fico y Tecnolgico

analytic.title: Suboptimal investment behavior and welfare costs: A simulation based approach

biblStruct.note: Received 18 April 2018; Received in revised form 29 August 2018; Accepted 21 September 2018 â Corresponding author.

textClass.keywords: Asset allocation Martingale method Portfolio selection Suboptimal investment Monte Carlo simulation Welfare loss JEL classification: D81 G11 G18 H55

div.p: We propose a representation of suboptimal investment behavior based on the stochastic discount factor (SDF) paradigm. Suboptimal investment behavior is rationalized as being the investor's optimal decision under a wrong SDF, while wealth trajectories and budget constraints are based on the true SDF. We develop a novel Monte Carlo simulation approach to compute the welfare costs for this suboptimal behavior.

We study the suboptimal portfolio choice under CRRA preferences using two financial market models. The Monte Carlo simulation delivers comparable welfare losses to those computed in the original studies, which are based on partial differential equations (PDE) and -finite-difference schemes.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Over the last twenty five years, behavioral financial economists have provided mounting evidence of suboptimal behavior among investors (e.g. excess trading, over-confidence, anchoring, framing, conservatism, herding behavior, under-diversification etc.).foot_0 At the same time, the theory of continuous-time optimal portfolio choice initiated by Merton (1971) has been extended to deal with ever more general preferences foot_1 and models of asset returns, foot_2 producing analytical solutions that facilitate the task of computing (either closed-form, or nearly) optimal portfolio rules. foot_3 In this paper, we propose a representation of suboptimal investment behavior that is based on the SDF paradigm, and develop a novel Monte Carlo (MC) simulation approach to compute the welfare costs due to suboptimal investment behavior. Our representation is based on the notion that suboptimal investment behavior can be rationalized as being the investorâ€™s optimal decision under the wrong SDF, while wealth trajectories and budget constraints are based on the true SDF, hence generating a welfare loss. We apply this simple idea to assess the welfare cost of suboptimal investment rules.

We study the quantitative implications of suboptimal portfolio choice under standard constant relative risk aversion (CRRA) preferences, using two different financial market models: the stochastic volatility model of Liu and Pan (2003), and the time-varying bond risk premia model of Koijen et al. (2010). In both cases, our MC simulation approach delivers comparable welfare losses to those computed in the original studies, both of which are based on partial differential equations (PDE) and - finite-difference schemes.

Our paper adds to the literature on two fronts. First, it proposes a way to rationalize suboptimal investment decisions using the SDF paradigm. If we have observable portfolio allocations, this relationship helps estimating a functional form of the SDF. foot_4 Second, it proposes a MC simulation approach based on the martingale approach to portfolio problems (e.g. Cox and Huang, 1989 and Karatzas et al., 1987. Recent applications can be found in CastaÃ±eda and Devoto, 2016 and Lim et al., 2017). Specifically, we use the well-known relationship between the SDF and the optimal policies that determine the investorâ€™s utility (e.g. consumption, terminal wealth etc.), to compute the welfare cost produced by solving the investment problem under both the true and the wrong SDF.foot_5

Our paper is related to several strands of the literature. The portfolio choice problem under consideration belongs to the Merton tradition. On the computation of welfare costs due to suboptimal investment behavior, this is related to Balduzzi and Lynch (1999);Campbell and Viceira (1999);AÃ¯t-Sahalia and Brandt (2001);Liu et al. (2003);Liu and Pan (2003);Kahl et al. (2003);Das and Uppal (2004);Cocco et al. (2005);Branger et al. (2008);Calvet et al. (2009);Branger et al. (2010);Koijen et al. (2010);Branger and Hansis (2012);Jin and Zhang (2012);Larsen and Munk (2012);Branger and Larsen (2013);Branger et al. (2013);Roche et al. (2013);Flor and Larsen (2014);Diris et al. (2014);Escobar et al. (2015) and Koijen et al. (2016), among others. All the papers above that consider continuous-time models, use some form of finite difference scheme to determine the welfare costs of suboptimal investment behavior, while ours relies on MC simulation. Finally, on the computation of nearly-optimal portfolio rules, our paper makes additions to the work of Haugh et al. (2006) and Bick et al. (2013).

div.head: The model
div.p: We consider a continuous-time portfolio problem with d â‰¥ 1 state variables Y_{i,t}, i,j = 1, ..., d, and d sources of Brownian uncertainty, W_{i,t}, i = 1, ..., d. State variables follow a vector diffusion process: dY_t = Î¼_Y(t, Y_t)dt + Ïƒ_Y(t, Y_t)dW_t, Y_0 âˆˆ â„^d given, where Î¼_Y(t, Y_t) âˆˆ â„^d and Ïƒ_Y(t, Y_t) âˆˆ â„^{dÃ—d} satisfy regular conditions for {Y_{j,t}}_{j=1}^d to be integrable processes, W_t = (W_{t,1},...,W_{d,t}), and the symbol (â€²) denotes the transposition of matrices and vectors.

The investor allocates his wealth between n risky securities, and one riskless security (a money market account) with an instantaneous rate of return r t â‰¡ r(t, Y t ). The security price S i, t satisfies the stochastic differential equation dS_{t,t}/S_{t,t} = (Î¼_t(t, Y_t) - Î´_t(t, Y_t))dt + Ïƒ_t(t, Y_t)dW_t, S_{t,0} > 0 given, where Î´_{t,t} â‰¡ Î´_t(t, Y_t) âˆˆ â„ the dividend rate, Î¼_{t,t} â‰¡ Î¼_t(t, Y_t) âˆˆ â„ is the (ex-dividend) expected return, and Ïƒ_{t,t}â€² â‰¡ Ïƒ_t(t, Y_t)â€² âˆˆ â„^n is the vector of volatility coefficients of security t. We denote by Ïƒ_t the n Ã— n-dimensional volatility matrix whose ith row is Ïƒ_{t, v}, and assume Ïƒ_t to be invertible.

We assume the market price of risk (MPR), Î¸_t = Î¸(t, Y_t) â‰¡ Ïƒ(t, Y_t)^{-1}(Î¼(t, Y_t) - r(t, Y_t)1), to satisfy the Novikov condition ğ”¼_0[exp(1/2 âˆ«_0^T Î¸_t*Î¸_t dt)] < âˆ, where 1 is a unit vector, and ğ”¼_0[Â·] stands for the mathematical expectation taken at time 0.
The financial wealth process of the investor, X t , evolves over time according to:
div.formula: dX_t/X_t = (1 - Ï€_t*1)r_t dt + Ï€_t*(Î¼_t dt + Ïƒ_t dW_t); X_0 â‰¥ 0 given; Ï€_t âˆˆ ğ’¦ âŠ† â„^d; âˆ«_0^T ||Ï€_t*Ïƒ_t||^2 < âˆ; X_t â‰¥ 0, âˆ€ t â‰¥ 0;(1)
div.p: where Ï€ t is the vector of wealth proportions invested in the set of risky assets, and is a convex set that summarizes the portfolio restrictions to which the investor's asset allocation problem is subject.
The preferences of the investor are given by a standard CRRA vN-M index,
where Î³ > 0 is the Arrow-Pratt coefficient of relative risk aversion.

div.head: The value function
div.p: Using the convex duality approach of Cvitanic and Karatzas (1992), it follows that the attainable time-T cash-flow that maximizes (2), subject to (1), is equivalent to the problem that maximizes (2) subject to the static budget constraint given by
where
div.formula: Î¾_T â‰¡ exp(-âˆ«_0^T (r_t + 1/2 Î¸_t*Î¸_t) dt - âˆ«_0^T Î¸_t*dW_t)(4)
div.p: is the arbitrage-free stochastic discount factor (SDF) that prevails in the absence of portfolio constraints (i.e. when ğ’¦ = â„^n), Î·_T â‰¡ exp(-âˆ«_0^T (Ïˆ(Î»_t) + Î»_t*Î¸_t + 1/2 Î»_t*Î»_t) dt - âˆ«_0^T Î»_t*dW_t) is an adjustment factor needed to enforce the portfolio restrictions over the optimal investment rule (i.e. Ï€_t* âˆˆ ğ’¦)foot_6 where Î»_t âˆˆ â„^n is a Lagrange multiplier vector process, and Ïˆ(Î»_t) â‰¡ sup_{Ï€_t âˆˆ ğ’¦}(-Ï€_t*Î»_t) is the support function of Î»_t. The optimal solution of this problem is given by
where
is the Lagrange multiplier of (3), and Ï â‰¡ 1 - 1/Î³. The multiplier is derived from the martingale condition ğ”¼_0[Î¾_T Î·_T X_T*] = X_0.
Combining (2), (5) and (6), it follows by direct computation that the value function of the problem when Î³ âˆˆ â„_{++}\{1}, is given by
where a(0, Y_0) = ğ”¼_0[(Î¾_T Î·_T)^Ï], and ğ’¦*(X_0,Y_0) is the set of investment rules that satisfy (1), and the condition U_0(X_T) < +âˆ. When Î³ = 1, we have
div.formula: J(0, X_0, Y_0) = ğ”¼_0[log X_T*] = log(X_0) - ğ”¼_0[log(Î¾_T Î·_T)](8)

div.head: The certainty equivalent loss
div.p: We rationalize the suboptimal behavior of the unsophisticated investor as being caused by the use of a wrong SDF when solving his/her portfolio selection problem, say Î¾Ìƒ_T Î·Ìƒ_T. In the literature, Î¾Ìƒ_T Î·Ìƒ_T usually corresponds to a simpler dynamics of the financial market, compared to the one that best fits the empirical evidence being presented (Das and Uppal, 2004;Branger et al., 2008;Branger et al., 2010;Koijen et al., 2010;Branger and Hansis, 2012;Jin and Zhang, 2012;Larsen and Munk, 2012;Branger and Larsen, 2013;Flor and Larsen, 2014;Escobar et al., 2015;Koijen et al., 2016, etc.). The unsophisticated investor acts rationally in the sense that it uses the same optimization problem to allocate. However, the misperception of this investor leads to use a wrong SDF and thus to deviate from the optimal allocation, as seen in (5). This means solutions (5) and (6) will change to X_T^{**} = (È³Î¾Ìƒ_TÎ·Ìƒ_T)^{-1/Î³} where this time È³ is derived from the martingale condition under the true SDF ğ”¼_0[Î¾_TÎ·_TX_T^{**}] = ğ”¼_0[Î¾_TÎ·_T(È³Î¾Ìƒ_TÎ·Ìƒ_T)^{-1/Î³}] = X_0 from where we have È³ = (X_0/ğ”¼_0[Î¾_TÎ·_T(Î¾Ìƒ_TÎ·Ìƒ_T)^{-1/Î³}])^-Î³.
When using the wrong SDF, the unsophisticated investor reaches the following level of expected utilityfoot_7
for Î³ âˆˆ â„_{++}\{1}, where b(0, Y_0) = \frac{ğ”¼_0[(Î¾Ìƒ_TÎ·Ìƒ_T)^Ï]}{ğ”¼_0[Î¾_TÎ·_T(Î¾Ìƒ_TÎ·Ìƒ_T)^{-1/Î³}]^{1-Î³}}. For the case Î³ = 1, we obtain

As a welfare loss measure, we compute the initial wealth loss needed by the investor following the optimal investment strategy to reach the same expected utility of the unsophisticated investor. In other words, we measure the welfare cost of suboptimal investment behavior as L_0 âˆˆ [0,1], where L_0 satisfies J(0,X_0(1-L_0),Y_0) = U_0(X_T^{**}).
When Î³ âˆˆ â„_{++}\{1}, note from Eq. (7) that J(0,X_0(1-L_0),Y_0) = (1-L_0)^{1-Î³}J(0,X_0,Y_0) = (1-L_0)^{1-Î³}U_0(X_T^*). Hence, the certainty equivalent (CEQ) loss is given by
When Î³ = 1, note from Eq. (8) that J(0,X_0(1-L_0),Y_0) = log(1-L_0) + J(0,X_0,Y_0) = log(1-L_0) + U_0(X_T^*). Thus

The expressions in (11) and (12) can be of help when values of X_T^* and X_T^{**} can at best be approximated by simulating trajectories of (Ï€_t^*,Ï€_t^{**})_{tâˆˆ[0,T]}, or some admissible approximation of these (e.g. Bick et al. (2013)). In the same vein, when the vector process (Î»_t)_{tâˆˆ[0,T]} can be determined, or at least approximated (e.g. Haugh et al. (2006)), we can use (7) and (9) to write
for the case Î³ âˆˆ â„_{++}\{1}. Likewise, we can use (8) and (10) to write

for the case Î³ = 1. The expressions above naturally call for Monte Carlo simulations as the numerical method of choice. In particular, we can estimate the CEQ loss by computing independent copies of the expression inside the expectation, and then taking the average of all of these. In doing so, we will need to use an Euler (time) discretization scheme, over the "right" and "wrong" SDE (Î¾_T and Î¾Ìƒ_T), and adjustment factor (Î·_T and Î·Ìƒ_T).

Extensions to more general HARA utility functions, including external habit-forming preferences, consumption-leisure decisions (Bodie et al. (1992,2004)), durable goods (Detemple and Giannikos (1996)), internal habit-forming preferences (Detemple and Zapatero (1992); Schroder and Skiadas (2002)), or finite-activity jump processes (Jeanblanc-PiquÃ© and Pontier (1990); Liu et al. (2003); Branger et al. (2008)), can be easily accommodated. All that is needed is a representation of the optimal payoffs (i.e. X_T^* and X_T^{**}) as computable functions of the "adjusted" SDF (resp., Î¾Î· and Î¾ÌƒÎ·Ìƒ). Two important cases that cannot be accommodated within the outlined framework are the cases of (Epstein-Zin) Stochastic Differential Utility (SDU) preferences, and jumps processes generated by an infinite activity process (Jin and Zhang (2012)). See, for instance, Detemple (2012) for a recent account on this matter.

div.head: Quantitative analysis
div.p: We conduct two numerical exercises to illustrate the application of the method.

div.head: Omission of an asset class
div.p: The first exercise explores the consequences of omitting an asset class in the asset allocation problem. In particular, it considers a simplified version (i.e. without jumps) of the model studied by Liu and Pan (2003) (hereafter LP), in a complete market with two sources of Brownian motion uncertainty (i.e. W âˆˆ â„^2), a constant interest rate (IR) and two risky assets: a stock index, and an option contract.
In this case, the stock index satisfies
div.formula: dS_t/S_t = (r + Î¸_{S,t}âˆšV_t)dt + âˆšV_t dW_{S,t}, S_0 given(15)
div.p: where Î¸_{S,t} is MPR of equity risk, and V_t follows a (Heston, 1993) dynamics, dV_t = Îº(VÌ„ - V_t)dt + Î·âˆšV_t(ÏdW_{S,t} + âˆš(1-Ï^2)dW_{V,t}), V_0 given, where (Îº, Î·, Ï) are constant parameters, Ï âˆˆ [-1,1] is the (instantaneous) correlation between dS/S and dV, and W = (W_S, W_V)â€² are two independent BMP.

The price of the option contract can be written as O_t = g(S_t,V_t), for some function g. An application of Ito's Lemma delivers dO_t = (rO_t + Î¸_{S,t}Ïƒ_{OS,t} + Î¸_{O,t}Ïƒ_{OV,t})dt + Ïƒ_{OS,t}dW_{S,t} + Ïƒ_{OV,t}dW_{V,t}, where Ïƒ_{OS,t} = âˆšV_t[g_SS_t + g_VÎ·Ï], Ïƒ_{OV,t} = âˆšV_tg_VÎ·(1-Ï^2)^{1/2}, with g_S = âˆ‚_Sg, g_V = âˆ‚_Vg, and Î¸_{O,t} as the MPR of volatility risk. Following Liu and Pan, we set Î¸_{S,t} = Î¸_SâˆšV_t, and Î¸_{O,t} = Î¸_OâˆšV_t, where (Î¸_S, Î¸_O) are two constant parameters.

The true dynamic of V_t is not observable, but we assume that it could be inferred with the data available in the market. We consider the case where the welfare cost is due to a wrong inference made on V_t. Specifically, we assume that the unsophisticated investor believes V_t to follow a time-varying deterministic GARCH(1,1) process (e.g. Corradi, 2000)

where (Ï‰_0, Ï‰_1) are constant parameters. Just like in LP, there are no portfolio constraints, that is Ï€_t = (Ï€_{S,t},Ï€_{O,t}) âˆˆ ğ’¦ = â„^2, which renders Î·_T = Î·Ìƒ_T = 1. The wrong inference on the volatility leads the unsophisticated investor to believe that the option contract is redundant in the portfolio choice problem. The unsophisticated investor dismisses the option contract, and hence the SDF used satisfies dÎ¾Ìƒ_t/Î¾Ìƒ_t = -rdt - Î¸_{S,t}dW_{S,t}, instead of the true SDF that satisfies dÎ¾_t/Î¾_t = -rdt - Î¸_{S,t}dW_{S,t} - Î¸_{O,t}dW_{V,t}foot_8. In this way we can compute the CEQ loss using the expressions in (13) and (14), by simulating trajectories of Î¾_T and Î¾Ìƒ_T, respectively.

To validate our simulation approach for estimating the welfare cost, we replicate the sensitivity analysis done by LP (Fig. 1). The loss estimated in LP derives from a strategy that does not use the derivative contract and a strategy that does, which equals the difference between using the true and wrong SDF in our exercise. Results are consistent. The CEQ loss amounts to nearly 30% of initial wealth in the basecase. As explained in LP, the demand for the option contract is driven mostly by the myopic component. That's why the loss is larger when Î¸_O deviates from zero and when risk aversion is smaller. The demand for the option contract increases and thus premium earnings on volatility risk. Similar to LP, the loss increases when both the initial volatility (V_0) and the stochastic component of the volatility (Î·) increase, because the hedging demand for the option contract increases too. The same happens when we increase the investment horizon. Fig. C.2 in Appendix C shows these same results but in terms of a management fee (explained latter in Exercise 2) and not the CEQ loss.

div.head: Missing intertemporal hedging demand
div.p: The second exercise explores the effects of not accounting for the intertemporal hedging demand, when the nominal interest rates (IR) process is stochastic. In particular, it considers the complete market version of the model studied by Koijen et al. (2010) (hereafter KNW), with 4 and four (instead of three) risky assets: two zero-coupon nominal bonds, an (added) inflation-linked security, and a stock index.
The KNW model contains a 2-dimensional state variable vector, Y_t = (Y_{1,t}, Y_{2,t})â€² âˆˆ â„^2, which evolves according to
div.formula: \begin{pmatrix} dY_{1,t} \\ dY_{2,t} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} Îº_{11} & Îº_{12} \\ Îº_{21} & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} Y_{1,t} \\ Y_{2,t} \end{pmatrix} dt + \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} dW_{1,t} \\ dW_{2,t} \\ dW_{3,t} \\ dW_{4,t} \end{pmatrix}(17)
div.p: (Y_{1,0}, Y_{2,0}) given, where (Îº_{11}, Îº_{12}, Îº_{21}) are constant coefficients. The nominal IR (r_t), is an affine affine function of Y_t satisfying r_t = Î²_{r0} + Î²_{r1}Y_t âˆˆ â„, where Î²_{r0} is a constant coefficient, and Î²_{r1}â€² âˆˆ â„^2 contains constant parameters. The prices of the risky assets evolve according to the following system \begin{cases} dB_t^{T_j}/B_t^{T_j} = (r_t + Ïƒ_{B_j,t}Î¸_t) dt + Ïƒ_{B_j,t}dW_t, B_0^{T_j} given, \\dS_{Î ,t}/S_{Î ,t} = (r_t + Ïƒ_{Î ,t}Î¸_t)dt + Ïƒ_{S_{Î ,t}}dW_t, S_{Î ,0} given, \\dS_t/S_t = (r_t + Ïƒ_SÎ¸_t)dt + Ïƒ_S dW_t, S_0 given,\end{cases} where B_t^{T_j} = ğ”¼_t[Î¾_{t,T_j}] is the (arbitrage-free) price of a nominal zero-coupon bond with maturity T_j, with 0 < T_1 < T_2 = T and Î¾_{t,T_j} â‰¡ Î¾_{T_j}/Î¾_t as the conditional SDF, Ïƒ_{B_j,t}â€² âˆˆ â„^4. S_{Î ,t} is the price of an inflation-linked security. Î _t is the price index with S_{Î ,t} = ğ”¼_t[Î¾_{t,T}Î _T] and Ïƒ_{S_{Î ,t}}â€² âˆˆ â„^4, S_t is the price of the stock-index, and Ïƒ_Sâ€² âˆˆ â„^4. We assume the volatility matrix, Ïƒ_t = (Ïƒ_{B_1,t}, Ïƒ_{B_2,t}, Ïƒ_{S_{Î ,t}}, Ïƒ_S), to be invertible. In addition, KNW impose the MPR as affine in the state variables, that is to say, Î¸_t = Î¸_0 + Î¸_1Y_t âˆˆ â„^4, with Î¸_1 âˆˆ â„^{4Ã—2}. Details on the calibration, which is based on KNW estimations, is given in Appendix A.

We consider the case where the welfare loss is due to the unsophisticated investor mistakenly assessing the time-varying nature of the investment opportunity set. Specifically, we assume that he/she wrongly perceives the nominal bond risk premia to be constant (i.e. Ïƒ_{B_j,t}Î¸_t â‰¡ x_{B_j}, for j = 1,2), where they are in fact stochastic (i.e. time-varying functions of Y_t)foot_9. We also assume the unsophisticated investor ignores the variation in the term structure of interest rates.

Admissible portfolio rules are subject to standard no short-sales and no borrowing constraints. To emulate the results from KNW, we add the restriction that the demand of the inflation linked security equals zero at all times. The set ğ’¦ is therefore given by ğ’¦ = {Ï€_t âˆˆ â„^4 : Ï€_{t,i} â‰¥ 0, âˆ€ i, Ï€_t*1 â‰¤ 1, Ï€_{3,t} = 0}

The adjustment factor Î·_T for set ğ’¦ is not known. Therefore, we simulate independent copies for the wealth X_t^* and X_t^{**} and determine the CEQ loss using Eqs. (11) and (12). To do this, we first compute the unconstrained version of the optimal and sub-optimal portfolio rules, Ï€_t^{*u} and Ï€_t^{**u} respectively; and then compute nearly optimal constrained portfolio rules from the latter.
From optimality conditions, it is easy to see that unconstrained optimal allocation satisfies

where a^u(t,Y_{1,t},Y_{2,t}) = ğ”¼_t[Î¾_{t,T}^Ï]. This is the optimal unconstrained portfolio rule (i.e. when ğ’¦ = â„^4) decomposed into its myopic and hedging demand terms. To compute the hedging demand we use the Monte Carlo with Malliavin Derivative (MCMD) method of Detemple et al. (2003). The details of this computation can be found in Appendix B.

The unconstrained allocation of the unsophisticated investor does not include the hedging demand, since the nominal bond risk premium and term structure does not depend on states Y_1 and Y_2. Therefore, we have
Appendix A shows the details in how to derive Eqs. (18) and (19). We define the nearly optimal portfolio policy for the constrained problem as (with x^+ â‰¡ max(x,0))
div.formula: Ï€^* = \begin{cases}Ï€_3^* = 0 \text{ and } Ï€_{i,t}^* = (Ï€_t^{*u})_i^+, & \text{if } b^u â‰¡ âˆ‘_{iâ‰ 3} (Ï€_t^{*u})_i^+ â‰¤ 1, \\Ï€_3^* = 0 \text{ and } Ï€_{i,t}^* = (Ï€_t^{*u})_i^+/b^u, & \text{otherwise.}\end{cases}(20)
div.p: The constrained policy for the unsophisticated investor Ï€^{**} is computed similarly, under the same rule in (20) and using Ï€_t^{**u}. The outlined procedure allows us to simulate independent copies of X_T^* and X_T^{**}, using (1) and the investment policies Ï€^* and Ï€^{**} respectively.

KNW estimate the loss of a life-cycle investor, when it conditions its decisions on wealth and age only and without considering the time-varying bond risk premia or the variation in the term structure of interest rates. Thus, this loss is comparable to the loss between Ï€^* and Ï€^{**}. Table 1 depicts the CEQ loss estimates, using the estimated coefficients in KNW. We also compute the welfare loss in terms of the same metric used by KNW, which is the maximum management fee (F) that can be charged when investing with the "correct" model (i.e. the true data generating process, or DGP) to end up with the same expected utility level as with the suboptimal strategy. The relationship between L_0 and F is given by (see further details in Appendix C)

Naturally, a greater welfare loss implies higher fees. Our results are consistent with the ones obtained by KNW. Fees are similar when we change the investment horizon, and loss magnitudes are close to 100 basis points (bp) for Î³ = 5 (value used by KNW). As expected, the loss measured in terms of fees is slightly lower when the investor is more risk averse.

div.head: Conclusions and further extensions
div.p: This paper proposes a way of rationalizing suboptimal investment behavior, based on the SDF paradigm. The proposed methorenders Monte Carlo simulation as the numerical method of choice to compute the welfare loss due to suboptimality. The proposed method can be applied whenever the optimal payoffs can be represented as computable functions of the "adjusted" (due to convex portfolio constraints) SDF.

We carry out two numerical exercises to illustrate the application of the method. One with a missing asset class (options), and a second one unsophisticated investor wrongly assumes the investment opportunity set to be constant. In both cases, we show that welfare cost due to suboptimality can be relatively high. These findings go somewhat against recent studies showing that the hedging component of optimal investment rules are of lesser importance (e.g. Diris et al., 2014;Lan, 2015).

Our representation of suboptimal investment behavior can also be used to assess model risk. In particular, a model risk could be conducted by using as the wrong SDF, the one that omits an important state variable, or misses a relevant source of risk (e.g. Branger et al., 2008;Branger and Hansis, 2012;Branger and Larsen, 2013;Kallsen and Muhle-Karbe, 2015). This representation could possibly allow the employment of the wrong SDF in misspecified models (e.g. Rubtsov, 2016;Jang et al., 2016) and estimate the losses with respect to a model without any misspecification.

figure.head: Fig. 1
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1 CEQ loss sensitivity results. The parameters of the base-case scenario are similar to those in LP, that is, Î³=2, Î¸â‚€=-6, âˆšVâ‚€=0.13, Î·=0.25, Îº=5, T=5 years, r=5%, Ï=-0.4.

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: CEQ loss L 0 (%) and equivalent management fee F (bp. per annun), for different risk aversion and time horizons T.

note.p: See, for instance, Barberis and Thaler (2003); Barber and Odean (2005); Benartzi and Thaler (2005); Calvet et al. (2007), (2009); Barber and Odean (2013) and Gaudecker et al. (2015), and the references therein.

See, for instance, Hindy and Huang (1992); Detemple and Zapatero (1992); Duffie and Epstein (1992) and Detemple and Giannikos (1996), for extensions beyond time-separable expected utility preferences, and Jian and Zhou (2008) for preferences that capture the proposals of prospect theory.

See, for instance, Heston (1993) and Broadie et al. (2007). There is also the issue of added parameter uncertainty that results from the estimation of a more complex specification, like in Barberis (2000); Garlappi et al. (2006); Kan and Zhou (2007) and Jang and Park (2016). In addition to standard time-additive expected utility, the more recent literature includes (internal) habit-forming preferences, recursive preferences, time-inconsistent preferences, and preferences consistent with cumulative prospect theory.

See, for instance, Kim and Omberg (1996); Wachter (2002); Detemple et al. (2003); Detemple and Rindisbacher (2005); Haugh et al. (2006); Detemple and Rindisbacher (2010) and Bick et al. (2013), and the references therein.
See, for instance, Koijen (2014) and Buraschi et al. (2014) for examples on the estimation of the SDF based on observable quantities related to portfolio choice problems.
Our representation holds for any preference model for which the optimal wealth can be represented as a function of the SDF.

In the specific case of incomplete markets, i.e. Ï€ i,t = 0 for some i = {1, ..., n}, we have Ïˆ(Î») = âˆ’Ï€â€²Î» = 0, and hence, Î· t = exp(âˆ«â‚€áµ— âˆ’Î»â€²t Î¸t âˆ’ Â½Î»â€²t Î»tdt âˆ’ âˆ«â‚€áµ— Î»â€²t dWt). See, for instance, Detemple and Rindisbacher (2005), Detemple and Rindisbacher (2010).

The expected utility under the suboptimal portfolio rule has the same functional form obtained by Branger and Larsen (2013) and Branger et al. (2013). This is in the spirit of Feynmanâ€“Kac; see, e.g. Proposition 2 in Detemple et al. (2008).

To be more precise, the redundancy of the option contract results in an infinite set of optimal portfolio policies, and hence, in the indeterminacy of any optimal portfolio rule. Setting Ï€_0,t\** = 0 is a simple way to avoid such indeterminacy.

As shown by KNW, when râ‚œ is affine in Yâ‚œ then Bâ‚œáµ€ = exp(náµ€(xâ‚œ) + máµ€(xâ‚œ)â€²Yâ‚œ), with náµ€(xâ‚œ) and máµ€(xâ‚œ) as deterministic functions of time-to-maturity, T = T âˆ’ t. Therefore, the nominal bond volatility can be written as Ïƒá´®â‚œáµ€ = háµ€(t)ÏƒÊ¸â‚œ + báµ€(t)Ïƒá´ Ê¸â‚œ, where háµ€(t) and báµ€(t) are deterministic functions of T âˆ’ t. Nominal bond risk premia, Ï€á´®â‚œáµ€ = Ïƒá´®â‚œáµ€Î»â‚œ, are therefore time-varying functions of Yâ‚œ.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The second author acknowledges financial support Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo CientÈ¡fico y Tecnolgico #11170012. We thank Jorge Sabat for providing excellent research assistance during the early stages of the research project.
